oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the Village of East Chester
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map of the Village of East Chester. Filed Oct 11, 1841. After the Erie Railroad came throught this section was know as "Chester at the Depot" for a time. Now known as Downtown Chester. Most of the depot grounds became G.M. Roe Lumber & Coal yard which was leased from the Erie RR. Many downdown parcels follow the lot lines proposed in this map to this day. Center Street survives, Highway became Main Street, turning into Railroad Ave. as it turns up the hill.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Maps; Measured drawings;
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: Map, linen; 18 by 11.5 in. (45.7 x 29.2 x 0 cm)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Prior written permission is required for any use of the images in this collection from the Chester Historical Society.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Erie RR Station Agent's Office
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is the only known photograph of the 1915 Chester Erie Station agent’s office taken while the station was in operation. It was taken in October, 1922 for use in the Erie Magazine. L-r: Robert Marvin, Station Master & John I. Edwards. Items observed in Station Agent's office: Ticket Window to Men's Waiting Room was replaced by a door during 1999 restoration (required by building code); New York City Telephone Directory; Great American Insurance Co. Calender; A.M. Wallace Calender; Conklin Lumber Thermometer (65F); Nicholas Owens Calender; Two person desk (see: Story of the desk below); Express Locomotive illustration; Chester National Bank Calender; Electric Meter & Service Disconnect Panel; 48 Star USA Flag; Cunard Lines RMS Aquitana (Sister Ship to the Titanic); F.S. Royster Guano Company, Baltimore Calender; "End of a Perfect Day"; Photo of President Warren G. Harding; Sam Vero Calender; Walter [Conklin] Builder's Supply, Chester Calender, Copy Press (A careful record of each transaction was kept in a logbook, stacked on the radiator. Copies made via wet process were sent to the Section Office the following day. Story of the desk: Bill Murray, interviewed by Norma Stoddard at the Farm Fest 2000-09-03, stated that: When the Chester Erie Station was to be closed in 1955, Don Barrell arranged for the desk to be given to the Chester Fire Dept. But since Sugar Loaf Fire Co. came into existence shortly after the Station actually closed, it went there. So the desk was put in the little building which was originally Sugar Loaf school house. It was in the right side in the office/meeting room at the Sugar Loaf Firehouse. The left side held two bays for the fire trucks. This desk returned to the Erie Station after forty five years as a gift from the Sugar Loaf Fire Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Group portraits;photographs;Railroad stations
Erie Railroad Company
Edwards, John I.; Marvin, Robert
Erie Railroad
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: Photograph, Print, 8 by 6 in. (20.3 x 15.2 cm)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Prior written permission is required for any use of the images in this collection from the Chester Historical Society.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: E. D. Green House
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of the E. D. Green House, built 1860 by James Hudson Board. He was descended from Cornelius and James Board, who settled in Chester before the Revolution, and from the Cornelius Board who was one of the early owners of the Durland Store in Chester Village. This house is cited in the 1875 atlas as J. H. Board, 120 acres and in the 1903 atlas as E. D. Green, 130 acres. It does not appear on the 1859 map. The house was originally built with an inverted roof, which funneled rain water into a cistern located in the basement. Problems with leaks prompted the construction of the conventional gabled roof.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Dwellings;photographs
Board, Cornelius, 1762-1830; Board, James Hudson; Board, James, 1720-1800?; Green, E. D., ?-1888
Architecture

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hambletonian Monument
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Photograph of the Hambletonian Monument located on Hambletonian Ave., at intersection with Oakland Avenue. “Hambletonian, "The Father of Harness Racers" owned by entrepreneur Wm Rysdyck. Rysdyck's horses "Long Island Black Hawk" and "New York Black Hawk" and finally Hambletonian did much to foster Goshen's Historic Track as the "Birthplace of the Trotter." Hambletonian was the most famous trotter in history. Died March 1876 and was buried here. Monument inscription: "Hambletonian, the Great Progenitor of Trotters. Born March 5, 1849. Died March 21, 1876”.”
by Donald F. Clark, Orange County Historian, 1975.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Photographs; Monuments; Horse racing;
Clark, Donald F.; Rysdyk, William Mapes, 1810-1870
Agriculture

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Henry Conklin & Wife
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Photograph of James Henry Conklin & Marry Ann with their dog in front of their home. Following his return from the Civil War, he and his wife lived in the house that became Conservo's Real Estate office, 1960's - 1980's. Now, 2007, it houses some of Gary Greenwald's law offices at 93 Brookside Ave., Route 17M, Chester.
James Henry Conklin was born in Deer Park, NY.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Board Farm
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Photograph of Board Farm on West Ave.
Jonathan Board, built the house in 1863. Originally, the house was built with an inverted roof system which funneled rain water into a cistern located in the basement. Leaks proved to be a problem and conventional gable roof was constructed over the house.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mountain View Game Preserve
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On the old Monroe-Chester road. Sign on tree: "Mountain View Game Preserve" as viewed from the farmhouse looking easterly. This is nown as the Thaddeus Seely Farm, "According to [Mildred Parker] Seese, Thaddeus Seely built this house in 1752. The Seely family was a widespread and prominent one in this area, and this house is probably the original family homestead. It is built in a simple, vernacular style with many early features. It has seen some modification and deterioration but its age and family association make it an important aspect of the history of the Town of Chester and of Orange County," By Donald F. Clark, Orange County Historian, June 1, 1977
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Photographs; Farms;
Clark, Donald F., Seese, Mildred Parker , 1902-?, Seely, Thaddeus, 1738-?
